definitions: the attitude or practice of accepting a situation as it is and being prepared to deal with it accordingly

examples.text: the summit was marked by a new mood of realism

shortDefinitions: attitude or practice of accepting situation as it is and being prepared to deal with it accordingly

definitions: the view that the subject matter of politics is political power, not matters of principle

examples.text: political realism is the oldest approach to global politics

shortDefinitions: view that subject matter of politics is political power

definitions: the quality or fact of representing a person, thing, or situation accurately or in a way that is true to life

examples.text: the earthy realism of Raimu's characters

notes.text: While realism in art is often used in the same contexts as naturalism, implying a concern to depict or describe accurately and objectively, it also suggests a deliberate rejection of conventionally beautiful or appropriate subjects in favor of sincerity and a focus on simple and unidealized treatment of contemporary life. Specifically, the term is applied to a late 19th-century movement in French painting and literature represented by Gustave Courbet in the former and Balzac, Stendhal, and Flaubert in the latter

shortDefinitions: quality or fact of representing person or thing in way that is accurate and true to life

definitions: (in art and literature) the movement or style of representing familiar things as they actually are.
shortDefinitions: artistic or literary movement or style characterized by representation of people or things as they actually are

definitions: the doctrine that universals or abstract concepts have an objective or absolute existence. The theory that universals have their own reality is sometimes called Platonic realism because it was first outlined by Plato's doctrine of “forms” or ideas.
shortDefinitions: doctrine that universals or abstract concepts have objective or absolute existence

definitions: the doctrine that matter as the object of perception has real existence and is neither reducible to universal mind or spirit nor dependent on a perceiving agent.
shortDefinitions: doctrine that matter as object of perception has real existence and is neither reducible
